facility.Name: Salt Marsh Nature Trail
facility.Location: Enter behind the Salt Marsh Nature Center, located near the intersection of East 33rd Street and Avenue U.
facility.Other_Details:
[Please note: The nature trail (east side of Gerritsen Creek) is being renovated; please visit the trails on the west side in the meantime.]
Crushed bluestone trail through a pristine salt marsh ecosystem along Gerritsen Creek. Interpretive signs along the trail provide the hiker with information regarding the history, flora and fauna of the area. Viewing platforms, excellent birding opportunities. Comfort stations and maps are available inside the Salt Marsh Nature Center (11:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m., Thursday - Tuesday, closed Wednesday).

facility.Name: Lullwater
facility.Location: Enter Park at Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue entrance. Trails begin or are near the Prospect Park Audubon Center.
facility.Other_Details: Explore the Lullwater to see how nature thrives in the heart of Brooklyn. The Lullwater is a great place to see birds and other wildlife. Bathrooms, cafÉ and trail guides are available at the Prospect Park Audubon Center.

facility.Name: Midwood
facility.Location: Enter Park at Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue entrance. Trails begin or are near the Prospect Park Audubon Center.
facility.Other_Details: Discover Brooklyn's last forest. The Midwood is home to some of the largest trees in Prospect Park. Bathrooms, cafÉ and trail guides are available at the Prospect Park Audubon Center.

facility.Name: Peninsula
facility.Location: Enter Park at Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue entrance. Trails begin or are near the Prospect Park Audubon Center.
facility.Other_Details: Discover how the Peninsula has changed over the last 300 years. The Peninsula's restored landscapes provide scenic views, a home for Park wildlife, and great fishing. Bathrooms, cafÉ and trail guides are available at the Prospect Park Audubon Center.

facility.Name: Waterfall
facility.Location: Enter Park at Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue entrance. Trails begin or are near the Prospect Park Audubon Center.
facility.Other_Details: Trace the source of the Lake on the Waterfall trail. The Fallkill Falls is the first of six waterfalls that you will see along the Park's watercourse. Bathrooms, cafÉ and trail guides are available at the Prospect Park Audubon Center.

facility.Name: Blue Trail
facility.Location: Behind ballfield 6 by Winchester Boulevard, north of Union Turnpike
facility.Other_Details: Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

facility.Name: Green Trail
facility.Location: Behind ballfield 6 by Winchester Boulevard, north of Union Turnpike
facility.Other_Details: Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

facility.Name: Orange Trail
facility.Location: Behind ballfield 6 by Winchester Boulevard, north of Union Turnpike
facility.Other_Details: Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

facility.Name: Ralph Sloman Trail
facility.Location: Behind ballfield 6 by Winchester Boulevard, north of Union Turnpike
facility.Other_Details: Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

facility.Name: Tulip Tree Trail
facility.Location: Cloverdale Boulevard east entrance
facility.Other_Details: Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

facility.Name: White Trail
facility.Location: Behind ballfield 6 by Winchester Boulevard, north of Union Turnpike
facility.Other_Details: Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

facility.Name: Yellow Trail
facility.Location: Behind ballfield 6 by Winchester Boulevard, north of Union Turnpike
facility.Other_Details: Numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds. The north end of the park boasts splendid salt marsh views.

facility.Name: Blue Trail
facility.Location: Forest Park Drive East, off of Woodhaven Boulevard
facility.Other_Details: Forest Park's numerous trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest and kettle ponds.

facility.Name: Orange Trail
facility.Location: Memorial Drive and Forest Park Drive East

facility.Name: Yellow Trail
facility.Location: Metropolitan Avenue & Forest Park Drive East

facility.Name: South Preserve Trail
facility.Location: Francis Lewis Boulevard and Union Turnpike
facility.Other_Details: Numerous unnamed trails wind through native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest.

facility.Name: Blue Trail (Southern Trailhead)
facility.Location: Brielle Avenue & Roanoake Street
facility.Other_Details: This is the Greenbelt’s longest marked trail. Its northeastern trailhead at the Greenbelt’s Deere Park can be accessed from Staten Island Boulevard. Walk the trail to its end, near the Brielle Avenue-Roanoake Street intersection in Willowbrook, and you will either pass through or have a view of each of the Greenbelt’s five distinct vegetation zones.

facility.Name: Nature Center Trail
facility.Location: Rockland & Brielle avenues
facility.Other_Details: This gentle walk takes you through a forest of red maple, black birch, cherry, tulip, and sassafras trees. In the understory, there is an abundance of spicebush, which produces bright red berries in the fall. The trail connects to the blue trail and the white trail.

facility.Name: Red Trail
facility.Location: Richmond Road and St. Patrick's Place
facility.Other_Details: Sites of interest include Heyerdahl Hill, the ruins of a 19th century vineyard estate, and a Bluebelt stormwater management pond in Egbertville. The trail skirts the golf course's edge.

facility.Name: White Trail (Southern)
facility.Location: Rockland Avenue near Brielle Avenue (mid-way trailhead) or Richmond Road near Reidel Avenue
facility.Other_Details: Connects to Great Kills Park of the Gateway National Park System Service.

facility.Name: Yellow Trail (Southwest Trailhead)
facility.Location: Richmond Avenue & Forest Hill Road
facility.Other_Details: Traverses the entire Greenbelt from its Northeast corner in the community of Todt Hill to its Southwest corner in New Springville; access Moses' Mountain at Rockland Avenue and Manor Road behind bus stop.

facility.Name: Pink Trail
facility.Location: Mulberry Avenue off Travis Avenue (limited parking)
facility.Other_Details: Excellent birdwatching location; abounds with water-loving trees such as sweet gum and ash.

facility.Name: White Trail (Northern)
facility.Location: Willowbrook Park off Victory Boulevard
facility.Other_Details: Connects to Great Kills Park of the Gateway National Park System Service.

facility.Name: Green Trail (Gretta Moulton Trail)
facility.Location: 200 feet ahead of parking lot at the terminus of Nevada Avenue
facility.Other_Details: The trail head of this circular trail is off the High Rock Park access road near the Nevada Avenue entrance. The hike takes you along kettle ponds and knobs, formations characteristic of terminal moraine topography. The upland forest includes a patch of persimmon trees. The trail is also known as the Gretta Moulton Trail in honor of an ardent Greenbelt supporter. Bathrooms nearby.

facility.Name: Lavender Trail
facility.Location: 200 feet ahead of parking lot at the terminus of Nevada Avenue
facility.Other_Details: Jewelweed, skunk cabbage, and various grasses and water plants can be seen, along with black water snakes, snapping turtles, and spring peepers. Bathrooms nearby.

facility.Name: Blue Trail (Northern Trailhead)
facility.Location: Staten Island Boulevard
facility.Other_Details: This is the Greenbelt’s longest marked trail. Its northeastern trailhead at the Greenbelt’s Deere Park can be accessed from Staten Island Boulevard. Walk the trail to its end, near the Brielle Avenue-Roanoake Street intersection in Willowbrook, and you will either pass through or have a view of each of the Greenbelt’s five distinct vegetation zones.

facility.Name: Cass Gallagher Nature Trail
facility.Location: A short walk in from the intersection of Broadway and Mosholu Avenue, near the horse stables

facility.Name: John Kieran Trail
facility.Location: Enter at Golf Course via Van Cortlandt Park South and Bailey Avenue.
facility.Other_Details: Maps are available at the Van Cortlandt Nature Center. Named in 1988 for the famed naturalist and newspaperman, this trail journeys through the park's lake area and freshwater wetlands, and forms a loop with the Parade Ground.

facility.Name: John Muir Trail
facility.Location: Enter either at Broadway & Mosholu Avenue or Van Cortlandt Park East & Oneida Avenue.
facility.Other_Details: Established in 1997, this trail is the only east-west path in Van Cortlandt and traverses the steep terrain at the park's center.

facility.Name: Old Croton Aqueduct Trail
facility.Location: Enter Trail at either Dickinson Avenue & Van Cortlandt Park South or Mosholu Parkway & West Gun Hill Road.
facility.Other_Details: [Trail renovations will begin soon. Please bear with us as we correct erosion and rebuild paths.] This segment is part of the 41-mile-long aqueduct that brought water from the Croton Dam to New York City in the 1800s.

facility.Name: Putnam Trail
facility.Location: Enter the park at Van Cortlandt Park South and Bailey Avenue.
facility.Other_Details: This section of the 15-mile trail that runs up to Brewster, NY may be accessed by the Van Cortlandt Golf Course parking lot. Native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest, historically significant route (former railroad route that ran through the park into the 1980s!)

facility.Name: Arden Woods Trail
facility.Location: Arden & Legate Avenue

facility.Name: Wolfe's Pond Trail
facility.Location: Hylan Boulevard & Cornelia Avenue

facility.Name: Long Pond Trail
facility.Location: Page Avenue & Eugene Street

facility.Name: Clove Lakes Park Trail
facility.Location: Victory Boulevard
facility.Other_Details: Includes views of wildlife, comfort stations, and a restaurant

facility.Name: Kazimiroff Trail
facility.Location: Hunter Island
facility.Other_Details: Native hardwood (oak-hickory) forest, salt marsh, vistas of Long Island Sound.
